alerts.message:
The National Weather Service in Tucson has issued a

* Flash Flood Warning for...
 southeastern Pinal County in southeastern Arizona...
 northeastern Pima County in southeastern Arizona...

* until 730 PM MST

* at 326 PM MST...Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated
 between 2.50 and 3.50 inches with isolated amounts up to 4 inches 
 of rain had fallen on the Santa Catalina Mountains. An automated 
 rainfall gage in Dan Saddle recorded 4.13 inches of rain. Although 
 this rainfall has occurred over several hours...this widespread and
 significant rainfall will result in flash flooding. The heaviest 
 rainfall has been in the Canada del Oro watershed. This runoff 
 takes several hours to make it down the mountain.

Additional watersheds that may experience flash flooding include 
Sabino creek and Bear Canyon on the southern side of the Catalina...and
the San Pedro river on the northeast side of the Catalina mountains. 

Precautionary/preparedness actions...

Excessive runoff from heavy rainfall will cause flooding of washes
and streams...urban areas...highways...streets and underpasses as
well as other drainage areas and low lying spots.


Lat...Lon 3240 11046 3236 11094 3259 11087 3259 11046

...Flash Flood Watch remains in effect through Tuesday
afternoon...

The Flash Flood Watch continues for

* a portion of Southeast Arizona...including the following 
 Baboquivari Mountains...Catalina ...and Rincon Mountains... 
 Chiricahua Mountains...Dragoon and mule and huachuca and Santa 
 Rita Mountains...eastern Cochise County below 5000 feet... 
 galiuro and Pinaleno Mountains...south central Pinal County... 
 southeast Pinal County...Tucson Metro area...upper Gila River 
 valley...upper San Pedro River Valley...upper Santa Cruz River 
 Valley/Altar Valley and White Mountains of Graham and Greenlee 
 counties. 

* Through Tuesday afternoon

* rainfall amounts from 1 to 2 inches have been experienced in
 many valley locations so far today...with 3 to 4 inches in some
 mountain locations. Additional rainfall amounts up to 1/2 inch
 in valleys are possible with isolated higher amounts. Up to 1
 inch additional rainfall possible in the vicinity of mountains. 

Precautionary/preparedness actions...

A Flash Flood Watch means that conditions are becoming favorable
for widespread flash flooding to develop. Monitor forecasts
closely and be ready to take quick action if flash flood warnings
are issued.

Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize
the dangers of flash floods. If flash flooding is observed...act
quickly. Turn around and take another Route.

Listen to NOAA Weather Radio...commercial radio or television
stations...or your cable television provider for updates on this
flash flood threat.



Meyer
